meta.title: Lines and Angles - Exercise 6.3 (Short Answer Questions)

questions.question: In Fig. 6.9, OD is the bisector of $\angle AOC$, OE is the bisector of $\angle BOC$ and $OD \perp OE$. Show that the points A, O and B are collinear.
questions.solution:
Given $OD \perp OE$, so $\angle DOE = 90^\circ$.
OD is the bisector of $\angle AOC$, so $\angle AOC = 2\angle DOC$.
OE is the bisector of $\angle BOC$, so $\angle BOC = 2\angle COE$.
Now, $\angle AOC + \angle BOC = 2\angle DOC + 2\angle COE = 2(\angle DOC + \angle COE) = 2\angle DOE$.
Since $\angle DOE = 90^\circ$, $\angle AOC + \angle BOC = 2(90^\circ) = 180^\circ$.
Since the sum of adjacent angles is $180^\circ$, A, O and B are collinear.

questions.question: In Fig. 6.10, $\angle 1 = 60^\circ$ and $\angle 6 = 120^\circ$. Show that the lines $m$ and $n$ are parallel.
questions.solution:
Given $\angle 1 = 60^\circ$ and $\angle 6 = 120^\circ$.
$\angle 1$ and the vertically opposite angle (let's call it $\angle 3$, interior on the left) are equal, so $\angle 3 = 60^\circ$.
Now, $\angle 3$ and $\angle 6$ are consecutive interior angles on the same side of the transversal.
Sum = $60^\circ + 120^\circ = 180^\circ$.
Since the interior angles are supplementary, the lines $m$ and $n$ are parallel.

questions.question: AP and BQ are the bisectors of the two alternate interior angles formed by the intersection of a transversal $t$ with parallel lines $l$ and $m$ (Fig. 6.11). Show that $AP \parallel BQ$.
questions.solution:
Since $l \parallel m$, the alternate interior angles are equal: $\angle MAB = \angle SBA$.
AP bisects $\angle MAB$, so $\angle PAB = \frac{1}{2}\angle MAB$.
BQ bisects $\angle SBA$, so $\angle QBA = \frac{1}{2}\angle SBA$.
Therefore, $\angle PAB = \angle QBA$.
These are alternate interior angles for lines AP and BQ with transversal AB. Hence, $AP \parallel BQ$.

questions.question: If in Fig. 6.11, bisectors AP and BQ of the alternate interior angles are parallel, then show that $l \parallel m$.
questions.solution:
Given $AP \parallel BQ$, the alternate interior angles are equal: $\angle PAB = \angle QBA$.
Since AP and BQ are bisectors, $\angle MAB = 2\angle PAB$ and $\angle SBA = 2\angle QBA$.
Therefore, $\angle MAB = \angle SBA$.
Since the alternate interior angles formed by transversal $t$ on lines $l$ and $m$ are equal, $l \parallel m$.

questions.question: In Fig. 6.12, $BA \parallel ED$ and $BC \parallel EF$. Show that $\angle ABC = \angle DEF$.
questions.solution:
Extend DE to intersect BC at a point P.
Since $EF \parallel BC$, $\angle DEF = \angle DPC$ (Corresponding angles).
Since $BA \parallel ED$, $AB \parallel DP$, so $\angle ABC = \angle DPC$ (Corresponding angles).
From both equations, $\angle ABC = \angle DEF$.

questions.question: In Fig. 6.13, $BA \parallel ED$ and $BC \parallel EF$. Show that $\angle ABC + \angle DEF = 180^\circ$.
questions.solution:
Extend ED to intersect BC at a point P.
Since $EF \parallel BC$, $\angle DEF + \angle EPC = 180^\circ$ (Consecutive interior angles).
Since $BA \parallel ED$, $AB \parallel EP$, so $\angle ABC = \angle EPC$ (Corresponding angles).
Substituting $\angle EPC$ with $\angle ABC$, we get $\angle ABC + \angle DEF = 180^\circ$.

questions.question: In Fig. 6.14, $DE \parallel QR$ and AP and BP are the bisectors of $\angle EAB$ and $\angle RBA$, respectively. Find $\angle APB$.
questions.solution:
Since $DE \parallel QR$, the consecutive interior angles sum to $180^\circ$: $\angle EAB + \angle RBA = 180^\circ$.
AP and BP are bisectors, so $\angle PAB = \frac{1}{2}\angle EAB$ and $\angle PBA = \frac{1}{2}\angle RBA$.
Summing them: $\angle PAB + \angle PBA = \frac{1}{2}(\angle EAB + \angle RBA) = \frac{1}{2}(180^\circ) = 90^\circ$.
In $\triangle APB$, $\angle APB = 180^\circ - (\angle PAB + \angle PBA) = 180^\circ - 90^\circ = 90^\circ$.

questions.question: The angles of a triangle are in the ratio $2 : 3 : 4$. Find the angles of the triangle.
questions.solution:
Let the angles be $2x, 3x$, and $4x$.
Sum of angles = $180^\circ$.
$2x + 3x + 4x = 180^\circ \Rightarrow 9x = 180^\circ \Rightarrow x = 20^\circ$.
The angles are $2(20^\circ) = 40^\circ$, $3(20^\circ) = 60^\circ$, and $4(20^\circ) = 80^\circ$.

questions.question: A triangle ABC is right angled at A. L is a point on BC such that $AL \perp BC$. Prove that $\angle BAL = \angle ACB$.
questions.solution:
In $\triangle ABC$, $\angle A = 90^\circ$, so $\angle ABC + \angle ACB = 90^\circ$.
In $\triangle ALB$, $\angle ALB = 90^\circ$, so $\angle BAL + \angle ABC = 90^\circ$.
Comparing the two equations: $\angle ABC + \angle ACB = \angle BAL + \angle ABC$.
Subtracting $\angle ABC$ from both sides, we get $\angle ACB = \angle BAL$.

questions.question: Two lines are respectively perpendicular to two parallel lines. Show that they are parallel to each other.
questions.solution:
Let lines $l \parallel m$. Let line $p \perp l$ and line $q \perp m$.
Since $p \perp l$ and $l \parallel m$, $p$ is also perpendicular to $m$ (A line perpendicular to one of two parallel lines is perpendicular to the other).
Now, both $p$ and $q$ are perpendicular to $m$.
Two lines perpendicular to the same line are parallel to each other.
Therefore, $p \parallel q$.
